unnormalised: IIT Kanpur prof, Dr. Arvind's lecture on Linear Algebra proved to be a real head-scratcher, even for the PhD students! Apparently, showing up with only 2 cups of chai didn't help ease the tension either. Sources say he went into a deep dive explaining eigenvalues and eigenvectors using matrices sized at 10x10 – manually!
normalised: I-I-T Kanpur professor, Doctor Arvind's lecture on Linear Algebra proved to be a real head-scratcher, even for the P-H-D students! Apparently, showing up with only two cups of chai didn't help ease the tension either. Sources say he went into a deep dive explaining eigenvalues and eigenvectors using matrices sized at ten by ten – manually!

unnormalised: One student, Aisha Khan, was overheard saying, "I thought I understood determinants, but after that, I'm not even sure I know 1+1 equals 2 anymore." Another quipped that he now understands why the textbook costs Rs. 1200 – because it takes that much effort to (maybe) understand the subject.
normalised: One student, Aisha Khan, was overheard saying, "I thought I understood determinants, but after that, I'm not even sure I know one plus one equals two anymore." Another quipped that he now understands why the textbook costs rupee one thousand two hundred – because it takes that much effort to (maybe) understand the subject.

unnormalised: The lecture apparently included a proof involving a "diagonalizable matrix" that took up 3 whiteboards and left everyone staring blankly. Some brave souls asked questions, only to be met with answers so complex, they triggered spontaneous existential crises. The lecture notes, reportedly, now feature prominently in a meme circulating on the IIT Kanpur campus.
normalised: The lecture apparently included a proof involving a "diagonalizable matrix" that took up three whiteboards and left everyone staring blankly. Some brave souls asked questions, only to be met with answers so complex, they triggered spontaneous existential crises. The lecture notes, reportedly, now feature prominently in a meme circulating on the I-I-T Kanpur campus.

unnormalised: Dr. Arvind, known for his unconventional teaching methods (and questionable fashion choices), defended his approach, saying, "Linear Algebra is like jalebi – twisted, complex, and ultimately, surprisingly sweet… once you’ve spent 5 years trying to figure it out." Attendance is expected to be higher next week, if only to figure out what exactly a "Rank-Nullity Theorem" actually means.
normalised: Doctor Arvind, known for his unconventional teaching methods (and questionable fashion choices), defended his approach, saying, "Linear Algebra is like jalebi – twisted, complex, and ultimately, surprisingly sweet… once you've spent five years trying to figure it out." Attendance is expected to be higher next week, if only to figure out what exactly a "Rank-Nullity Theorem" actually means.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, the Maths department is reportedly considering adding a "Coping with Linear Algebra" course to the curriculum, with the first lecture titled: "Is it supposed to make sense? (Spoiler alert: Maybe not)".
